oai_dc:dc.dc:title: "The Naturalist" article on the peach-tree worm
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Agriculture; Periodicals; Insects
Agriculture; Periodicals; Insects; Agricultural pests
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: "The Naturalist" article, page 311, contains an illustration of the various stages of the peach-tree worm. The writing is done under the Agricultural Department section of the serial and emphasizes the fact that entomology was a frequent subject that was covered in the interests of Tennessee farmers.
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Fanning, Tolbert, 1810-1874
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Tolbert Fanning founded this scientific journal as well as another journal. "The Agriculturalist," which was the journal of the State Agricultural Society. He embraced the ideas behind scientific agriculture, and he was also an early leader of the Stone-Campbell movement in Tennessee, a form of Christianity. Franklin College, a manual labor school that included farm work and Bible study, was located five miles east of Nashville. It was eventually closed down after the Civil War.
